docs.lead_paragraph: At his inauguration as Puerto Rico's re-elected Governor earlier this month, Pedro J. Rossello apologized to those who find him ''stubborn, obsessive, even intransigent.'' He then promised more of the same for his next four-year term, including forging ahead with a new plebiscite to get the island and the United States to redefine their nearly century-old relationship once and for all. ''It is the responsibility of this generation, facing the new millennium, to define clearly, decisively and finally the route of our political destiny,'' Mr. Rossello said from the grounds of El Morro, the four-century-old fort that provided a backdrop of Spanish colonialism for the Governor's reference to what he and other supporters of statehood for Puerto Rico regard as its modern-day American version.

headline.main: Governor of Puerto Rico Presses Battle for Statehood

docs.snippet: At his inauguration as Puerto Rico's re-elected Governor earlier this month, Pedro J. Rossello apologized to those who find him ''stubborn, obsessive, even intransigent.'' He then promised more of the same for his next four-year term, including...

docs.lead_paragraph: AS he approaches his second swearing-in, Bill Clinton, that avid student of history, has been rummaging through the second-term inaugural addresses of Presidents past and thinking about junctures in American history when a leader helped transform the nation. Great Presidents like Franklin D. Roosevelt and Abraham Lincoln and great moments of change in society most often come out of the crucible of war or economic turmoil, Mr. Clinton has told his aides. But sometimes a peacetime President can seize the moment. And for at least a year now, Mr. Clinton has been turning for inspiration to Theodore Roosevelt, the roughriding Republican trustbuster from Oyster Bay, L.I.

headline.main: Speaking Softly In the Bully Pulpit

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, on eve of his second inaugural, is studying second-term inaugural addresses of Presidents past and thinking about junctures in American history when a leader helped transform the nation; he has turned for inspiration to Theodore Roosevelt, saying his speeches moved the country into the future; Roosevelt has many points of appeal for Clinton; he made powerful use of what he called the President's 'bully pulpit,' and Pres Clinton, faced with Republican Congress, has become more interested in oratorical potential in his office; photos (M)
docs.snippet: AS he approaches his second swearing-in, Bill Clinton, that avid student of history, has been rummaging through the second-term inaugural addresses of Presidents past and thinking about junctures in American history when a leader helped transform the...

docs.lead_paragraph: The unraveling of the Soviet Union released a tidal wave of educated emigrants, thousands of whom settled in Brooklyn's Brighton Beach and other vibrant Russian enclaves. Their intellectual curiosity and growing affluence have given rise, by one count, to 38 Russian-language papers, plus a cable television channel, the Russian Television Network. The Moscow newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets has published a New York weekly, B Novom Svetye, since 1995. Until recently, New York's only Russian daily, Novoye Russkoye Slovo, founded in 1910, seemed stalled in a prerevolutionary time warp, with a dated Cyrillic logo and drab format that put off all but the most homesick emigre. But the conservative paper -- whose name means New Russian Word -- has redesigned itself, with a stylistic facelift and a livelier editorial content, and claims a circulation of 65,000 copies.

headline.main: Russians Learn Secrets of the New World, and Some From the Old
headline.kicker: A Tower of Babel, in Wood Pulp

docs.lead_paragraph: SOCIAL SECURITY may not be broke -- yet -- but there are already plenty of ideas about how to fix it. The recent report from a Federal advisory panel of experts, who split into three factions because they were unable to agree on any full solution, only underscores the range of clashing views on one of the most vexing social and economic problems facing the nation.

headline.main: Promises to Keep: Rethinking the Future of Social Security

docs.abstract: Debate developing from recent Federal advisory panel report on possible reforms to Social Security system discussed; views of several prominent experts, three from Advisory Council on Social Security and three others representing varying viewpoints, noted; experts are: Richard Thau, executive director of Third Millennium, Dean Edward M Gramlich and chairman of Advisory Council, Carolyn Weaver, director of Social Security and pension studies at American Enterprise Institute and Advisory Council member, Robert M Ball, former Commissioner of Social Security Administration and Advisory Council member, Peter G Peterson, chairman of Blackstone Group, investment banking firm, and John Rother, director of legislation and public policy for American Assn of Retired Persons (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the last year, the widespread use of combinations of new and older drugs has changed the face of AIDS, promising to transform a fatal infection to a manageable chronic disease. There are several combinations, many that include the new protease inhibitors, or antiviral drugs. All can drive the amount of H.I.V., the AIDS virus, below the levels of detection in the blood for up to 18 months, which is as long as testing has been done. With such therapy, some individuals have left their death beds and many who were less seriously ill are leading more normal lives.

headline.kicker: HOPE VS. HYPE -- A special report.

docs.abstract: Combinations of new and old drugs used to treat people with AIDS and HIV encourage great hope, but also disappointment for an unknown number of patients; failures with the drugs, including new protease inhibitors, prompt questions about whether unrealistic expectations have been encouraged, whether some people do not respond because they have received wrong drug combinations, whether AIDS-damaged immune system can ever be restored to normal and whether health officials are doing enough to monitor strains of HIV that have become resistant to new therapies; graphs show how three patients responded to combination drug therapy (L)
docs.snippet: In the last year, the widespread use of combinations of new and older drugs has changed the face of AIDS, promising to transform a fatal infection to a manageable chronic disease.    There are several combinations, many that include the new protease...

docs.lead_paragraph: On the trial of Jesse K. Timmendequas in the murder of Megan Kanka: ''Just because he did something like this 10 years ago doesn't mean he did it this time. Up until now anyway, in our system we don't confine people because they are dangerous. We confine them only if they commit a crime.'' RICHARD SINGER, a professor at Rutgers University School of Law in Camden On new school report cards that grade on more than 150 skills in 10 subject areas: ''Teachers are finding that the old reporting system doesn't do justice to what's going on in the classroom. They want to make more precise judgments about kids' strengths and weaknesses.'' GRANT WIGGINS, a consultant in Princeton who helps schools revise report cards ''The information we were reporting before didn't match what the kids were learning. And parents wanted more.'' JIM MEMOLI, curriculum coordinator for the South Orange-Maplewood school district ''Even if they get the best scores, it's not a big boost of confidence. It's nice to call your grandparents and tell them you got all straight A's on your report card.'' DEBBIE GAFGEN, whose two sons attend elementary school in Hamilton On the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, now under construction in Newark: ''Our aspiration is to grow into an institution that can stand shoulder to shoulder with Lincoln Center and the Kennedy Center. Our architecture and acoustics reflect that goal, the scale of what we are doing reflects that goal and our programming reflects that goal.'' LAWRENCE P. GOLDMAN, president of the center ''It is being built by nonresidents for nonresidents. They will come in and get dumped off at the front, see the show and then leave without having any impact on the community. I see it like those practice landings at the airport where they put their wheels on the ground and then take straight off again.'' ''You still have a very unsafe city. They need better schools, better health care and better police force, and then the changes will flow from there.'' RAYMOND M. CODEY, director of development for the New Community Corporation On restructuring car insurance: ''My proposal is about choice. Giving consumers choices so they can decide what's best for them. Not trial lawyers. Not insurance executives. And not any of the others who have found the current system so lucrative. Let's put motorists back in the driver's seat.'' GOVERNOR WHITMAN in her State of the State address ''You will get the $1.98 policy that covers nothing. You will find yourself in a desperate situation. People will take the lowest policy, and God forbid they would get hurt.'' JOSEPH V. DORIA Jr., a Democrat from Hudson County and the Assembly Minority Leader

docs.lead_paragraph: JUDITH HELFAND was 14 when she heard about DES, a drug given to five million women from 1938 to 1971 to prevent miscarriages. Ms. Helfand was home from Kennedy High School in Bellmore because of a broken leg when she saw a talk show about DES, the synthetic estrogen diethylstilbestrol, a and its legacy. Of the 2.4 million daughters of the women who took DES, half have malformed reproductive organs or child-bearing problems, and 1 in 1,000 has developed or is expected to develop DES-related cancer. ''I was struck by the idea of these mothers taking a drug to have a baby,'' Ms. Helfand recalled. ''And now these babies can't have babies.''

headline.main: A Victim of DES Puts Experience Into a Documentary

docs.abstract: Judith Helfand discusses her documentary film experience as DES daughter, one of 2.4 million women who have malformed reproductive organs or have had cancer because their mothers took synthetic estrogen drug to prevent miscarriage years ago; film, A Healthy Baby Girl, recounts hers and mother's experience dealing with Helfand's infertility and cancer surgery; interview; photos; documentary is being shown at Sundance Film Festival; major financing came from public television and Jewish filmmaking fund supported by Steven Spielberg (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN someone recommends real estate as a good, steady investment for those worried about iffy times, survivors of the real estate boom and bust of the 1980's might be stunned. But they should get used to it. The companies known as real estate investment trusts, or REIT's, are now commonly seen as a good way to invest defensively. The 1996 record of these ventures, which own, manage and develop properties, is a powerful lure. While the Standard & Poor's 500 had a total return of almost 23 percent last year, REIT's gained nearly 36 percent, according to the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts.

headline.main: Seeking Shelter in Real Estate Trusts

docs.abstract: Real Estate Investment Trusts (REIT's), despite recollections by some investors of real estate boom and bust of 1980's, are now commonly seen as good way to invest defensively; 1996 record of these ventures, which own, manage and develop properties, is powerful lure; while S&P 500 had total return of almost 23 percent last year, REIT's gained nearly 36 percent, according to National Assn of Real Estate Investment Trusts; photo; some REIT's recommended by analysts noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is a Chinese proverb that says, ''A man's life is but a candle in the wind.'' This is never more true than when you are traveling. Flights can be grounded or missed; ferry schedules can change; the weather in Boca or Bora-Bora can turn nasty, and every room in the perfect little Left Bank hotel can be taken (even though you have a reservation). When I first started traveling to write this column three years ago, I lived in fear of these sorts of mishaps, which are often costly and time-consuming. I grew superstitious, giving my seats on subways and buses to elderly ladies in order to accrue good karma, and stopping in Catholic churches to light candles for the positive outcome of my trips.
docs.abstract: Frugal Traveler column on necessity of thorough planning before taking a trip; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Jan. 11 editorial ''Tax Reform, 10 Years Later'' wisely encourages Congress to limit deductions by businesses for health insurance. What your editorial does not mention is that a cap on this deduction could be the basis for bipartisan health care reform in the 105th Congress.

headline.main: Use a Small Tax Reform to Help the Uninsured

docs.abstract: Letter from Flint J Wainess says Jan 11 editorial on tax reform does not mention that proposed cap on deductions by business for health insurance could be basis for bipartisan health care reform in 105th Congress (S)
